conclusion: To solve this problem, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph of two objects, A and B, moving along the same straight line from the same starting position.
The graph shows the velocity of each object as a function of time.
Identify the starting position on the velocity-time graph. This is the point where both objects begin moving.
Observe the velocity-time graph for both objects. The graph shows the velocity of each object as a function of time.

premise: The velocity is the slope of the graph.
conclusion: Determine the time at which the two objects are farthest apart. This occurs when the distance between the two objects is at its maximum.
From the graph, identify the time \( t_1 \) when the distance between the two objects is at its maximum. This is when the velocity of object A is greater than that of object B.
Identify the time \( t_2 \) when the distance between the two objects is at its minimum. This is when the velocity of object A is less than that of object B.

premise: Since the objects start from the same position, the time at which they are farthest apart is the difference between \( t_2 \) and \( t_1 \).
conclusion: Calculate the difference between \( t_2 \) and \( t_1 \) to find the time at which the two objects are farthest apart.

premise: Verify that the calculated time matches the reasoning process.
conclusion: At time \( t_2 \), the two objects are farthest apart.
